<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_virt2phys:
```c
static int metal_virt2phys(void *addr, unsigned long *phys)
{
	off_t offset;
	uint64_t entry;
	int error;

	if (_metal.pagemap_fd < 0)
		return -EINVAL;

	offset = ((uintptr_t)addr >> _metal.page_shift) * sizeof(entry);
	error = pread(_metal.pagemap_fd, &entry, sizeof(entry), offset);
	if (error < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed pagemap pread (offset %llx) - %s\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, strerror(errno));
		return -errno;
	}

	/* Check page present and not swapped. */
	if ((entry >> 62) != 2) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "pagemap page not present, %llx -> %llx\n",
			  (unsigned long long)offset, (unsigned long long)entry);
		return -ENOENT;
	}

	*phys = (entry & ((1ULL << 54) - 1)) << _metal.page_shift;
	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: The rest of the code in metal_virt2phys uses standard C constructs and POSIX APIs, not language extensions: casting a pointer to uintptr_t, use of fixed-width integer types (uint64_t), bitwise shifts, constant integer suffixes (1ULL), and calls to pread/strerror/errno are standard or POSIX and do not constitute compiler language extensions per MISRA Rule 1.2. The function's control flow and return usage (returning negative errno constants) do not use any compiler-specific language extensions. Therefore only the macro definition (which contains a GCC statement-expression '({ ... })' form and the use of '##__VA_ARGS__') and its call sites need investigation for possible use of compiler-specific extensions.
